results.name: Number of canonical Gray cycles of length 2n.
comment: By a canonical Gray cycle (CGC) of length 2n is intended a mono-cyclic permutation of the integers {0,1,2,...,2n-1} such that (i) it starts with "0", (ii) the binary expansions of any two adjacent terms of the cycle differ by exactly one bit, and (iii) the last term is larger than the second. Note: there are no CGC's of odd length.

For n>1, a(n) is also the number of all distinct Hamiltonian circuits in a simple graph with 2n vertices, labeled 0,1,2,...,(2n-1), in which two vertices are connected by an edge only if the binary expansions of their labels differ by exactly one bit.
The sequence is a superset of A066037: A066037(n)=A236602(2^(n-1)).
link: Sykora S., On Canonical Gray Cycles, Stan's Library, Vol.V, January 2014, DOI: 10.3247/SL5Math14.001.
example: a(5) = 4 since there are only these 4 CGC's of length 10:

Join[{1}, Table[ct = 0; A236602[n, {0}, Range[2 n - 1]]/2, {n, 2, 8}] ](* _Robert Price_, Oct 25 2018 *)
